title-group.subtitle: Cognitive Development Correlates With Lesion and Electroencephalographic Features

article-meta.aff: 1Developmental Neurology Division, Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Neurologico C. Besta, via Celoria, Milano, Italy
2Department of Neuroradiology, Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Neurologico C. Besta, via Celoria, Milano, Italy
3Department of Neurophysiology, Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Neurologico C. Besta, via Celoria, Milano, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Daria Riva, MD, Developmental Neurology Division, Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Neurologico C. Besta, Via Celoria 11, 20133, Milano, Italy. Email: driva@istituto-besta.it

abstract.p: The purpose of this study was to assess cognitive development in 26 children with congenital focal brain lesion and unilateral spastic cerebral palsy first diagnosed and followed up for rehabilitation at our institution. Mean intelligence quotients (IQs) were correlated not only to the different features of the cerebral lesions, but also to the different types of electroencephalographic abnormalities. We also examined individual scores. We found that about 70% of the children had values of Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQs within the normal range. No differences were found between left and right injured children. Different Verbal IQ–Performance IQ profiles were observed. Larger lesions and some electroencephalographic features, mainly signal slowing/attenuation as signs of structural brain damage, were significantly associated with lower intellectual abilities. The role of other factors, including genetic and environmental background variability, as well as rehabilitative treatments, on cognitive sequelae in such patients was discussed.

body.p: Congenital focal brain lesions are acknowledged to be associated not only with motor and neurosensorial deficits but also with a variety of complex neuropsychological and behavioral sequelae. The type, timing, and asymmetry of the lesion in such conditions provide the unique opportunity to study the impact of an early, nonprogressive disease and the role of infantile cerebral plasticity and of functional hemispheric asymmetry on cognitive development.

In children suffering early cerebral lesions, the remarkable plasticity of the developing brain has been well documented.1,2 Cognitive functions have been reported to be widely spared, confirming the capacity of functional reorganization in the developing brain.3 However, functional recovery in multiple cognitive domains can be variable.4,5 Although most of the previous studies showed that overall cognitive development was within the normal range at school age,6,7 others reported that a cognitive impairment was obvious since the first years of life.8,9 Furthermore, some authors showed that cognitive functioning may differ at the individual level from the average results of the group of patients.10

Several and mutually dependent factors (eg, insult severity, age at insult, environment) were reported to influence cognitive outcome and the underlying phenomenon of neuroplasticity in children with congenital brain lesions.11 The age at occurrence of the event was reported to be relevant. Cerebral maturational level can influence not only the degree of hemispheric specialization and plasticity but also the functional development of the different cortical areas that occurs at different stages of postnatal development.12,13

Although many authors did not find any relationship between the functional language abilities and the laterality of the congenital lesions,14–17 others did.18,19 Similarly, the role of the lesion severity resulted in controversial results.20–22 Albeit the well-documented capacity of functional reorganization in the developing brain, the localization of the lesions was reported to be relevant for the onset of possible neuropsychological sequelae. Some kind of cortical specialization was suggested to be in place since birth, and children with unilateral brain lesions may show site-specific deficits or the impairment of more distributed networks involving injured areas.13,23,24 Other constraints such as the integrity of the surrounding and contralateral homotopic areas were also reported to influence brain plasticity.21,25,26

The presence of epilepsy was also suggested to play a negative prognostic role on cognitive development.25,27–31 This was more obvious when children had chronic epilepsy32,33 and/or seizures occurred at an early age. These findings were related to the alteration of maturational processes, mainly of myelin, in the sites where the epileptic abnormalities were more recurrent.34

The aim of the present study was to define the impact of early focal lesions on intelligence profile in a cohort of children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy secondary to congenital brain damage. In addition, because active epilepsy is rare in hemiplegic cerebral palsy,35 we wished to consider not merely the presence/absence of seizures but rather the role of the different electroencephalographic (EEG) features on postlesional cognitive reorganization. We hypothesized that the size of the lesion and the different patterns of epileptiform activities and other EEG findings could be associated with different cognitive outcomes.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: This is a prospective, single-institution, cross-sectional study. Between 2003 and 2005, 31 children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy were enrolled and followed up at C. Besta Neurological Institute in Milan, a centre of excellence for children with cerebral palsy.

Patients were selected according to the following inclusion criteria: (1) presence of hemiplegic cerebral palsy and unilateral hemispheric lesion confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); (2) absence of major behavioral disorders; (3) absence of brain malformations; (4) good compliance with the examinations; and (5) written informed consent by the parents.

Twenty-six children (15 males) with congenital brain damage (mean age, 10 years 10 months; range, 7 years 3 months to 14 years 6 months), diagnosed and followed up for rehabilitation at our Institution since the first year of life were enrolled in the study. All the children had congenital unilateral hemispheric lesions and a contralateral hemiplegic cerebral palsy. As it is usually observed in Italy, all the participants attended regular classes with or without a special teacher working on individual learning programs. They all underwent or had undergone the same rehabilitative therapy (type and intensity) in infancy or early childhood, including speech, occupational, and physical therapy.

Table 1 shows lesion/neurological data on the congenital brain damage. All the subjects were administered the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children–Revised36 as part of a wider neuropsychological assessment involving children with cerebral palsy referred to our Institution. Data of Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQs were collected.

fn.p: Abbreviations: AIS, arterial ischemic stroke; PVL, periventricular leukomalacia; w.m., white matter.

sec.title: Brain Imaging
sec.p: Magnetic resonance imaging examinations were acquired on a 1.5 Tesla system. Conventional imaging included sagittal T1-weighted images (TR = 556 ms, TE = 13 ms, field of view = 230 × 230, matrix = 230 × 256, section thickness = 6 mm) axial PD/T2-weighted images (TR = 3500 ms, TE = 17 ms/84 ms, field of view = 208 × 256 mm, matrix = 208 × 206, section thickness = 5 mm), and coronal turbo spin-echo T2-weighted images (TR = 4100 ms, TE = 143 ms, field of view = 324 × 384 mm, matrix = 324 × 384, section thickness = 5 mm). The images were assessed by a single senior neuroradiologist (AE) not involved in patient care and blinded to subject’s status.

Brain damages were classified according to the type, side, site and size. The vascular territory of the brain damage was also provided according to the Damasio and Damasio atlas.37 In addition, signal and structural abnormalities in the ipsilateral corticospinal tract, thalamus, corpus callosum, and optic radiations were assessed for degeneration and loss of the fibers secondary to vascular damage. The size of the lesion was rated on a 3-point scale: 0.5 = mild (0.5-2 cm), 1= moderate (2.5-4 cm) and 1.5 = severe (>4 cm). We assessed white matter degeneration by assigning 0.5 points when abnormal signal intensity was present in the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle, visual pathway, thalamus, or corpus callosum, and 1 point when atrophy was present in addition to abnormal white matter signal intensity. The total damage score for each child was obtained by adding the score for size of the vascular lesion to that for secondary Wallerian degeneration, because both represent consequences of a single injury.

sec.title: Electroencephalographic Recording
sec.p: Digitized EEG was recorded with 20 electrodes (10–20 International System) together with polygraphic derivations (electro-oculography, spirogram, and submental electromyogram) and included a 20-minute period of wakeful state with closed eyes, intermittent photic stimulation and hyperventilation, and at least 1 non-REM sleep cycle. The EEG signal was recorded using longitudinal bipolar montages. Several recordings were available for most patients and the last EEG examination, obtained within 2 months with respect to the neuropsychological assessment was chosen for the evaluation. An individual expert neurophysiologist (SF), not involved in patient care and blind with respect to the clinical/neuropsychological assessment, evaluated the EEG signals.

The presence of hemispheric/local slowing or signal attenuation was scored according to an arbitrary scale: 0 = no pathologic findings; 1 = mild slowing/attenuation; 2 = moderate slowing/attenuation. No patients showed severe abnormalities or severe hemispheric/local slowing. The presence and characteristics of epileptiform activities were scored 0 = none; 1 = epileptiform activity, with characteristics similar to those commonly observed in benign “genetically determined” childhood epilepsies38; and 2 = any other epileptic activity.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: SPSS 10.0 for Windows was used to screen and analyze all data. Data for the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children–Revised (Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQs) were analyzed using independent-sample t test using lesion laterality (left lesion vs right lesion) and type (periventricular leukomalacia vs arterial ischemic stroke) as independent variables. Paired-samples t test was used to compare the Verbal and Performance IQs within all clinical groups.

Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare the size of the lesions between the subgroups divided according to the side and the neuropathology of the lesion. Correlation test was used to evaluate the relationship between IQs and clinical variables (lesion size and EEG features). Because the size of the lesions and EEG features were not adequately normal to perform a parametric test, we used the Spearman correlation test. All statistical analyses were 2-tailed, and P values of .05 or lower were considered significant.

sec.title: Brain Imaging
sec.p: Details are shown in Tables 1 to 3. Two types of vascular damage were found: white matter lesions due to periventricular leukomalacia and cortical-subcortical lesions due to arterial ischemic stroke of the cortical branches of the middle cerebral artery. Fifteen of the 26 children with congenital brain damage had brain lesions on the left hemisphere; the remaining 11 showed lesions on the right hemisphere. Fifteen of the 26 had periventricular leukomalacia (9 on the left, 6 on the right hemisphere); the remaining 11 had arterial ischemic stroke (6 on the left, 5 on the right hemisphere).

caption.p: Hemispheric Damage Scores in Children With Left Lesions.
Hemispheric Damage Scores in Children With Right Lesions.

sec.p: The size and site of the lesions for each child were accurately described in Tables 2 and 3. The mean size of the right lesions was greater than that of the left lesions, but the difference was not significant (U = 52.5, P = .118). Mean lesion size in children with arterial ischemic stroke was higher than children with periventricular leukomalacia (U = 45, P = .051).

sec.title: Electroencephalographic Findings
sec.p: The individual EEG findings are shown in Table 1. Eleven of the 26 children with congenital brain damage did not show any local or hemispheric slowing abnormality or signal attenuation, 6 showed mild hemispheric slowing/attenuation (score 1), the remaining 9 had moderate slowing abnormalities or signal attenuation (score 2). Eleven of the 26 children with congenital brain damage showed epileptiform activities; 6 of the 11 had centrotemporal spikes that increased during sleep recordings, and whose location, morphologic characteristics, and time course were similar to those characterizing rolandic benign epilepsies and were scored 1; the remaining 5 showed focal (1 child), multifocal (3 children), or diffuse (1 child) epileptiform activities and were scored 2. Nineteen of the 26 children never had seizures.

sec.title: Cognitive Outcome
sec.p: Individual values of Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQ of children with left- and right-sided lesions are shown in Table 1. Mean values of Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQ and t test P values are shown in Table 4. Verbal IQ–Performance IQ difference was close to significance in the whole sample (t = 1.872, df = 25, P = .073). Mean Verbal IQ was significantly higher than mean Performance IQ in children with arterial ischemic stroke (t = 2.417, df = 10, P = .036), whereas no different profiles were found within the periventricular leukomalacia, left and right injured groups. The size of the lesion negatively correlated with Full-Scale IQ and Verbal IQ (P = .016 and P = .026, respectively) in the whole group.

caption.p: Mean and Standard Deviation for WISC-R Verbal IQ, Performance IQ, and Full-Scale IQ With P Value for Independent-Samples t Test Using Laterality and Type of Lesion as Independent Variables and Paired-Samples t Test Comparing Verbal IQ and Performance IQs Within All Clinical Groups.

fn.p: Abbreviations: AIS, arterial ischemic stroke; CBD, cognitive brain damage; LL, left lesion; PVL, periventricular leukomalacia; RL, right lesion.

sec.p: Total EEG scores negatively correlated with all IQs (ρ = −0.782, P = .000 for Verbal IQ, ρ = –0.727, P = .000 for Performance IQ, ρ = –0.853, P = .000 for Full-Scale IQ). More specifically, signal slowing/attenuation negatively correlated with all IQs (ρ = –0.708, P = .000 for Verbal IQ, ρ = –0.892, P = .000 for Performance IQ, ρ = –0.863, P = .000 for Full-Scale IQ), whereas epileptiform activities negatively correlated with Verbal IQ (ρ = –0.459, P = .018) and Full-Scale IQ (ρ = –0.406, P = .040).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study showed that about 70% of children with congenital brain damage in our cohort had values of Full-Scale, Verbal, and Performance IQs within the normal range. These findings are in keeping with previous studies reporting that children with congenital brain damage often show cognitive development within the normal range.6–7,9,18,29,39–42 However, other authors reported a certain degree of cognitive impairment since the first years of life.8,9 As suggested by animal43 and human studies,5,44 the good prognosis in cognitive development and other neuropsychological domains in a proportion of children with congenital brain damage reflects the presence of mechanisms for postlesional recovery in the developing brain dealing with early insults. Over the past few decades, several studies investigating the impact of early brain lesions on development of cognition reported that early lesions are more likely to be associated with better outcomes than those observed in similar insults occurring later in life.3,18,28,39,40,45 This supported the evidence that early rather than late brain injury leads to a more satisfying outcome as a consequence of more flexible cortical plasticity. More recently, however, these statements were not confirmed by other studies assessing children with different timing of brain insults.46,47

When we analyzed the individual results, we found that 11 children with left and 7 children with right hemisphere lesions had Full-Scale IQ within the normal range, whereas the remaining 8 showed a Full-Scale IQ below the normal values ranging from 79 and 67. The Verbal-Perfomance IQ discrepancy was significant only in the children with arterial ischemic stroke and in the sample as a whole.

All the 4 children with left-sided lesions and Full-Scale IQ <85 (Nos. 1, 9, 10, 15) had large lesions albeit different in nature (2 arterial ischemic stroke and 2 periventricular leukomalacia) and moderate slow abnormalities or signal attenuation on EEG recordings. The 4 children with right-sided lesions and Full-Scale IQ <85 had either a large cortical-subcortical infarction (No. 24) or severe EEG abnormalities (No.19) or both (Nos.21, 23).

In our cohort, lesion side was not associated to side-specific intellectual effects, as no differences were found between left- and right-injured children. The children with left lesion had mean values of Verbal IQ within the normal range, in contrast with the results expected in adults with similar patterns of lesions (Verbal IQ < Performance IQ). It is of note that Verbal > Performance IQ pattern was more frequently observed in children with left hemisphere lesions (10/15), although this finding was obvious also in more than half of the children with right hemisphere lesions (6/11). Most of the studies assessing long-term cognitive sequelae of early unilateral lesions investigated left hemisphere lesions. The similarity of mean Verbal IQ between left and right brain injured groups is in contrast to the laterality of language abilities that becomes obvious after unilateral strokes in adults. Typical development leads to the neuroanatomical distribution of language systems predominantly to the left hemisphere,48 which develops more left lateralized throughout childhood.49 Although early left-sided injuries are supposed to be associated with greater language impairment than right-sided lesions, these differences are reported to be more obvious very early in language development and to disappear in subsequent years.50 It has been reported that lesions localized in brain areas specifically involved in language processing may promote different patterns of postlesional reorganization. As in adults, this could figure either an intrahemispheric (or bihemispheric) or an interhemispheric reorganization, according to the shift of function within the ipsilesional or to the contralateral hemisphere.51–56 Thus, as recently reported by us and others by means of functional MRI studies and/or dichotic listening tasks,54,57,58 a left-sided lesion may induce postlesional intrahemispheric or interhemispheric reorganization of language. This has been shown to be influenced mainly by the extent of the lesion57 and by the involvement of thalamus.58

The children with arterial ischemic stroke showed a significant Verbal >Performance IQ discrepancy as a group, with Verbal IQ values higher in 4 of the 6 children with left-sided lesions involving language networks. This compensatory capacity could be attributed to the earlier maturational processes occurring in the right hemisphere, where a larger amount of genes controlling neuronal proliferation and migration localized in the perisylvian cortex are expressed during the first years of life.12 We may argue that Verbal IQ was higher than Performance IQ in children with left-sided injuries because language shifted to the right hemisphere. The right hemisphere, characterized by longer maturational times, may be able to compensate linguistic deficits due to left hemisphere lesions.18,19,40,51–56 These findings, however, should be interpreted with caution as we did not perform any functional assessment aimed to evaluate functional organization of language in our cohort. According to several authors, this capacity of compensation skilled by the right hemisphere would correspond to a loss of the circuital networks available to those functions typically processed by the right hemisphere, with the subsequent lowering of Performance IQ and visuoperceptual abilities.19,59 This phenomenon, known as crowding effect, was first described by Sperry and was further confirmed by several clinical studies and recently by functional MRI studies performed in children with congenital brain lesions.51–53,56

However, subject by subject analysis showed that in 5 of the 15 children with left-sided injury, Verbal IQ was lower than Performance IQ, as expected in adults experiencing similar patterns of lesion. Four of the 5 had a periventricular leukomalacia (1 with thalamic wallerian degeneration), the remaining one had an arterial ischemic stroke involving language areas.

More than half (6/11) of the children with right lesion showed Verbal IQs significantly higher than Performance IQs, whereas 4 of the remaining 5 had Performance IQs higher than Verbal IQs with a difference lower than 10 points. They all had Full-Scale IQs at the lower level of normal range (1 child) or even lower (3 children). They showed significant EEG abnormalities, which could have hampered the global maturation of high cognitive functions lowering the expected pattern of functional asymmetry.

It is of note that in our cohort the type of the lesion was associated with different cognitive outcomes. Cortical-subcortical lesions secondary to arterial ischemic stroke were associated with the worse cognitive outcome in comparison with white matter lesions secondary to periventricular leukomalacia. These findings could be partially due to the sizes of the lesions, which were larger in infarcts.

In children with periventricular leukomalacia, the side of the lesion can produce Verbal-Perfomance IQ patterns similar to those observed in cortical-subcortical arterial ischemic lesions. In our cohort, 3 of the subjects with left-sided periventricular leukomalacia (Nos. 2, 3, 11) had Verbal IQs within the normal range (and higher than Performance IQs); they did not show any involvement of subcortical white matter with sparing of associative fibers. Conversely, 3 other children with left-sided periventricular leukomalacia and a diffuse subcortical white matter involvement (Nos. 1, 6, 7) had Verbal IQs lower than Performance IQs. We may hypothesize that a left intrahemispheric language reorganization occurred in such children. Verbal IQ was 13 points higher than Performance IQ in the remaining child with left-sided periventricular leukomalacia (No. 10). This could suggest right-shifting of the language and penalization of Performance IQ as observed in arterial ischemic lesions. A few studies reported that white matter lesions, mainly when they involve associative fibers, may be associated with site-specific neurobehavioral deficits.60,61 In our children with periventricular leukomalacia and left-sided injury, white matter lesions extensively involved motor projection fibers in the anterior thalamic radiation, fibers in the corticopontine tract, fibers from the primary sensorimotor cortex to the thalamus, fibers in the corticorubrum tract and commissural radiations of the corpus callosum. Fibers projecting from the occipital lobe, as well as Graziolet’s radiation from lateral corpus geniculatus, are located in the posterior part of the subcortical white matter, whereas fibers projecting from the temporal lobe, the acoustic radiation, and the temporal corticopontine tract, are localized in the inferior part. In addition, periventricular leukomalacia, can also variably involve the frontooccipital associative fasciculus. Periventricular leukomalacia may extensively disrupt projective and, to a less extent, associative fibers, producing a global more than a selective malfunctioning.

The size of the lesion was found to be a negative prognostic factor on cognitive development in our cohort, mainly in the children with left-sided injuries. This proves the relationship between larger sizes and greater cognitive impairment and consequently the role of the severity of the lesions.20–22 Previous studies resulted in contradictory results. Although some authors found a relationship between larger sizes of the lesions and greater cognitive impairment,17,2022,62 others showed that smallest and largest lesions led to better outcomes than lesions with intermediate sizes.44 Conversely, other studies found no relationship between size of the lesions and the level of impairment.9,27,63

Not surprisingly, EEG findings, that is, signal slowing/attenuation and epileptiform activities, were significantly associated with low IQs in all subjects in the sample as a whole. However, we found that direct signs of brain damage suggested by signal slowing/attenuation rather than the presence of epileptiform abnormalities significantly correlated with cognitive impairment. In our cohort, 6 patients showed epileptic activities whose characteristics could fit those commonly observed in childhood “functional” epilepsies. Although a few authors reported that these epilepsies may cause mild neuropsychological disfunctioning,64,65 this impairment is inconstant and usually mild. The presence of “benign” epileptiform patterns in symptomatic patients is not surprising. They were reported in different pathologic conditions, including chromosomal or genetic abnormalities66,67 and various types of structural damage.68 These findings may suggest that circuitry changes due to genetic or early-acquired brain pathologies may contribute to generate rolandic spikes fitting a picture of rolandic epilepsy, without modifying its benign prognosis. The presence of local or diffuse epileptic abnormalities whose characteristics suggested a symptomatic epilepsy conversely indicated a more severe and persistent circuitry rearrangement resulting from the brain damage. In our cohort, a more severe cognitive impairment correlated with the presence of EEG slowing and/or attenuation of the background activity. These abnormalities are nonspecific EEG findings and can be found in different chronic and acute pathologic conditions. They are acknowledged to be due to structural brain damages69 and are more likely to give rise to consistent circuitries malfunction. Similarly, slow activities rather than focal epileptic activities were found to correlate with neuropsychological defects even in populations of children with epilepsy.70

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, we found that in children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy secondary to congenital brain damage, the mean IQs were generally preserved, but at the individual level larger lesions and some EEG features, mainly signal slowing/attenuation as signs of structural brain damage, were more frequently associated with lower intellectual abilities. Different Verbal-Performance IQ profiles were observed in our subjects, suggesting that multiple factors other than those commonly investigated (lesion features and the presence/absence of seizures) may influence postlesional reorganization and recovery. To date, the mechanisms of redistribution of the abilities processed by the different hemispheric areas following early brain injury remain unclear and to infer intrahemispheric versus interhemispheric reorganization on the basis of clinical observations remains speculative.

The potential and specific cognitive development that each child could have on the basis of his or her genetic predisposition (eg, verbal abilities better than nonverbal capacities and vice versa) is an unknown factor that could at least partly influence postlesional outcome.

This study had the advantage of studying a sample of children with congenital brain damage followed up at the same institution and, more importantly, undergoing similar rehabilitative treatments. This latter aspect has been little considered in previous works. A few animal and human studies demonstrated that enriched environment and intensive rehabilitation may promote complex functional reorganization71 and reactivate critical periods of plasticity.72 These findings highlight the role of rehabilitation and environmental stimulation in inducing and modeling plasticity and should be taken into account when evaluating sequelae of early brain lesions.11

In conclusion, results by us and others on children with early unilateral brain lesions should be interpreted with caution, as different factors other than the injury itself, such as genetic and environmental background as well as rehabilitative treatments may induce molecular changes and structural repairing mechanisms which are different among the different subjects, as shown by our subject-by-subject analysis.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: Our sincerest and grateful appreciation is extended to all of the children and their parents whose participation was crucial to this research.

fn.label: Authors Contributions
fn.p: DR designed the study, drafted the manuscript, and supervised the study. DR and GB interpreted the data. SF evaluated the EEG data. SF, AE, GB, SE, and SB revised the manuscript. AE evaluated the MRI data. SE and SB were responsible for acquisition of data. SB performed statistical analysis.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Ethical Approval
fn.p: The study protocol was approved by our Institutional Review Board.
